transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: I'm just starting now? Okay my name is Jerry Dell Brown. I'm 42 years old. I caught my charge which is second degree murder at the age of 18 which was in 1995. And I have currently been locked up 22 years so this will be 23 years.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure, okay so the point of this is just to learn more about you and your experiences and so I'm just going to ask you about the first 18 years of your life and then we'll talk a little bit about the circumstances of the charge and mainly about your time since then, the last 22 years or so. So let me start by asking you about the folks who raised you. Tell me about your family.

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: I was raised by my grandmother. When I say raised I mean, at the age I was spending learning that I was a person that I can really see what's going on that was my grandmother but my mother, she had me, she was when she had me when she was 18 so she was fairly young so she used to leave us with our grandmother a lot. So our grandmother ended up raising her kids which was 4 two girls and two boys so our grandmother's actually the mindset behind the mind of a young boy so to speak.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure, and so tell me a little bit about your siblings.

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: Oh yeah, so my sister I have one brother, Derek, and two sisters both of my sisters are older than me. I'm the oldest son.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, so you're third in the birth order.

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: Yeah. I have a younger brother.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure, so let me rephrase it. So if you had to pin point somebody who was closest to you who took the greatest interest in you when you were coming up, who would that be?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: My sister. She was actually one who was forced into a mother role before her time.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Your oldest sister?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: Yeah, she had to actually do the mother thing when Mom was at work or there was no one there because there was a lot of kids. And so she, by her being the oldest grandchild, so she was forced into that role.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yep and so how many years older was she than you?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: I think she would be about 44, 45. So she's only like three years older than me.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: And where were you raised?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: Shreveport, Louisiana.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay so, I don't think this is kind of a typical situation here I think with Grandma. Is it safe to say that you grew up knowing that you were cared for and loved or did you feel like you kind of had to fend for yourself?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: I think it's kind of both. The greater one would be knowing that you were cared for and loved but the tangibles was kind of harder to see because it was so many kids and with so many kids, it's kind of hard to keep your eyes on one in particular so it's just like spread out.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, alright, friends. Did you have close friends that still stick by you that still stand by you in your mind?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: Yeah, as a matter of fact, I went to my grandmother's funeral last year and a lot of guys, they just saw me, even though I was in handcuffs when I went there, they weren't coming to the front row/funeral until they saw me and when they saw me, even after twenty years, when they saw me, they still were like "Man, there goes Jerry Brown."

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: So they came over there and began to talk with me and whatsoever and then liked hugged me and was like "Man, that's our friend" Said they were going to be in contact or and that they were sorry for not being in contact but we were going to be and I tell you, one of them actually kissed me on the jaw and you could tell.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: And have they been in contact with you since then?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: Yeah, really through my mother, yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, who visits you up here?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: My mother and my sisters.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, both sisters?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Alright. So tell me what's Tamika doing?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: What's her job? Oh, she's Dr. Tamika Brown. She has a doctorate degree in Theology and so she preaches and does things in church.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: In Shreveport?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What about your other sister and your brother?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: Beautician. She has a degree or something too. I know one of them is cosmetology, I guess, but she has her own beauty shop.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay and your other sibling?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: My brother, he lives in Texas.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What does he do?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: Some odd jobs. He has like two jobs actually, yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So you're not particularly close with him, he doesn't get up here very often?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: Because of that. He has a lot. I understand, yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: But, were you in Shreveport proper or so were you in an urban environment growing up or in a suburban environment?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: No, it was urban.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Suburban- urban. So you can you describe the housing so if I'm sitting on your front stoop driveway, can you paint a picture for me? What am I looking at?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: Yeah, well actually we used to have a like the flat projects like more like, I kind of think I remember seeing them like New Orleans, I've never been to New Orleans but I see pictures of the place and they have like the duplex houses and these they flat on the top.

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: Well, they had some of those across the street, but mostly on our street, it's really Small Street but it has houses lined up. It's only about 4 or 5 brick houses on the street and we lived in one of the brick houses actually on the street but it's, every house has a fence to the front to the back and a yard from this street to that street.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, what's going on? Is there a lot of people?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: Yeah, covered like ants.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Fights? Fighting in the neighborhood?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: Yeah. High intensity. A lot of drugs, arguing, drinking. These are kind of things that I wasn't a drinker or a smoker because of this. I saw so much people who OD'd off of drugs and I'm talking about right then so I'm a young boy looking at this. People getting shot, killed right in front of me so I'm seeing all this and yeah he's shot.

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: I'm talking about his blood splashing on me and my mom had to come out and get me because somebody thought I got hit and I didn't so, I thought about that since I been here. Those type of experiences, traumatic experiences of being placed in an environment that had that type of traumatic events going on every day. It was chaotic, really chaotic. But it's an amazing thing because on the opposite side of it, there was love.

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: There was still a sense of there was love. There was a sense of caring. There was a sense of affection. But still, you had this ugly, grim outside every day. It's like the sun goes down, or even sometimes in broad daylight, these events are happening- dudes may have a wreck, jump out the car shooting. I'm talking about right there women and children have to get out the way. This every single day.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure, did you think of your home as just a refuge from that?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: No because it was in there too.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah, okay, so tell me a little bit about that.

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: I had a couple of family members who was on drugs and as a result of that there's a lot of situations that occur in the house like people stealing. You got these kids in here, you got this old lady, which is my grandmother, and you got others who don't use drugs and who try to have nice things like VCRs and things would come up missing and this is where the arguments and the fights because you taking things that's not for you and using them for something else.

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: And the key is especially me, I was really observant and how there's fighting over money. There's fighting over cars. There's fighting over TVs, everything is a fight, where's those arguments are actually physical.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Were there any men in your mother's life that came into your life as a result of your relationship?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So tell some of those, any of those conflict of any type?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: Yeah. Well, matter of fact, this was a question you have on the paper that talks about somebody being intimate saying which one of your family members like that you loved the most? And it was actually her because I looked at her like the world. And one of things that I liked about my momma is that she could fight. She was a great fighter. I ended up becoming a boxer here so I'm going to add that to it too. But my mom was a great fighter. That's something that was kind of it wasn't looked down on where I'm from.

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: If you was a good fighter, it also had its what I would call symbolic meaning to- meaning that you was a person who was not going to just allow anything to happen without putting up a struggle so she met this guys named Percy. I was going to write a book about him called "No Mercy Percy" He was very abusive to her. He was very abusive and he used to beat my mom and so I came in to stop her one time and he wanted to beat her up right in front of us. As little boys, me and my little brother because my sisters didn't live with us.

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: It was just me and him and he would beat her up right in front of us and I'm talking about he was big. He was a dude and he would just beat her up and what traumatized me the most about him in the respect of her is that that's not the same lady I saw. She had become weak. She put up more of a fight in life that I had saw compared to what she allowed herself to go through because of her affection for him.

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: And he was abusive. And she finally got the heart to leave him once he turned his anger toward us. When he turned his anger toward us that was the final straw. As long as it was on her, it was good, but when he turned his anger on her kids, she left him.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: How old were you when all this was going on?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: I was about I had to be about 10 or 11 because I played baseball.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So, you got violence all around you. It's out in the street in your neighborhood and at home. So, where did you how did you get away from it all? Was there any place where you could escape to?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: You know what? I'm glad you asked that question because you just helped me to realize something. I used to have a bike and I used to get on that bike and I'd just ride and I'd go way up to my really far away and I never thought about where I was going, I would just go far as I could, I would stop and go in a store or something, buy something to drink and I'd come all the way back but the one thing that I do remember that I noticed was how I loved people.

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: I loved to meet people while I go to these places. I'm telling you, I would go a long way. I would be so far that when I go back, they would ask me, "Where you been all day?" I was like "I don't know" I just went somewhere just to get away and stay away.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah. You know a bike in a kid's life can be like a ticket to freedom especially if you are trying to get away from something. I can see that. What about school? How was school for you? Did you like school? Were you good in school?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: School was the exact same thing as the streets. There was drive-bys at our school, shootings, I mean. After school, there was war. Because I came from Shreveport. Shreveport is very gang-related. So and I remind you it was '86, '87 when I was like 12 or 13. I played basketball and football and track but it was just after school there was a war.

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: There was a war between the Crips and the Bloods and walking home like one time, I fought four or five dudes at the same time. All these guys jumped me and my friends stood right there. He didn't swing a blow to help. I had to fight and they tried to throw me in front of the city bus but some kind of way the bus missed.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Wow. What was there- what was their beef with you?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: There's somehow I let them, a guy wanted to borrow a gun and I went to his house and asked a question and he found out about it. It was an honest question but he found out about it and instead of coming ask me, he walked up to me and started punching. We just started fighting so all his friends jumped in.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: And your 12?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: Yeah, I'm like 12, I'm in 7th grade.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: You're 7th grade and you're having a conversation about a gun. So were firearms easy to get? A part of your life?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: No, it wasn't a part of my life but there was everywhere. Yeah, they weren't a part of my life. I was neither a gangbanger at the time nor was I am in drugs or alcohol.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay and you're a child, sure. So, would you characterize your childhood as being physically abusive?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: Yeah, by the environment, but not necessarily by the family. Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So, you've mentioned that no mercy Percy would sometimes turn his $$ towards you kids. That's when your mother had had enough of it. Did that go on for a while?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: Yeah, for a couple of years. One of the reasons that I feel like it really traumatized me per say was because of how I felt toward her. How I knew. I think I was the child that asked the most questions. And I used to talk to her a lot and she would tell me things that I don't think she told the rest of the kids because of my questions and I knew that she wanted to be successful and when she finally came got us and moved us to Spring Texas, everything she had told me about, it looks like she was having it.

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: She had a really nice job, she lived in a well-to-do neighborhood, brick house, three bedrooms, two cars, and she was doing well. She was doing well. She was like 27 so I was imagining that everything that she had contemplated beforehand, her soul reason of leaving us with our grandmother, it was now coming into fruition, but now the sad part about it is now who you choosing to share this with, he's the enemy, your downfall.

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: So now that everything you done positive, he was going to do it for you and that's exactly what happened. She had an accident at work where boxes fell on top of her. She was in a stocking room area and the boxes fell down on her and it cracked her tail-bone and as a result, she sued the company but they put her on some medicine that had cocaine in it. Yeah, back in those days, they used certain drugs for I guess as a pain but anyways, my mother ended up getting hooked on cocaine crack after. So, it just went worse, AWOL.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So, Spring Texas, so how long? When was the Spring Texas part of your life? Is this this charge happened in Shreveport right? So you're in Shreveport and you move to Texas for a little while?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: Yeah. That's when I was around 10 or 11.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay and when do you come back to Shreveport?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: About that was around 12.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay so that was not long.

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: Not long just a couple of years.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay was there any sexual abuse in your life?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: No.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay so tell me you told me a little bit about school but you basically said it was an extension of the fighting in the street, especially after school let out.

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: Man, it was notorious.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What was the name of your school?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: Midway middle school. This school was on the news and everything, yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay what was the highest year of school you completed?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: Tenth.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So you went on to high school. What was your high school?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: Well, same thing because it's right down the street.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay and was that midway high school?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: Yeah. But Midway middle school is here at Fairpark, the same place Morris Lee Claiborne for the Dallas Cowboys. He came from the same school, but its right down the street. Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So you finished 10th grade, why did you stop?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: I got kicked out. Fighting.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay and then what are you doing? So you're not in school.

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: Well, I actually I had a chance to become a boxer because of police guy detective. He saw my school records that I was really smart and he like "You good grades." He said "But you have a behavior problem." It was because of the fights and these guys was getting seriously beat up, not just a typical they was getting hurt badly and so he wanted to help me become a boxer. He said maybe this could be something that could be used as something to help you instead of.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: To channel some of that.

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: Yeah, some of that. Some of the anger and energy you have can be channeled into something positive. And when I came to Angola and I started boxing, even the person you see today part of came from boxing. Boxing taught me how to like if something angers me, instead of lashing out or allowing some kind of fury something to come out to think about it, to relax, to understand that how to have proper judgment and see something that's not worth building a hill over, something not worth that.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: How does boxing teach you that?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: Because boxing teaches you to be patient. It teaches you to.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: To wait for your time.

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: Time, good answer. It teaches you to be patient. It teaches you to see a target, all of us aren't good targets. It teaches you to know that you want to do something and continue to do it until you have it, until you accomplish it. It teaches you that pain sometimes is a builder, not a destroyer. And that's what boxing taught me. I teach a lot of boxers too now. Yeah, I'm a trainer now.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So what about girlfriends?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: Oh yeah, my son's mother.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Tell me about her.

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: Well, she was another one that I actually wrote a story about her, about her situation. I knew inside of my own head even on the street that I needed to be saved from it. And what I knew that something to be was death. Around my career, a lot of guys my age didn't live long and when I met her, she was like more of a mother to me. She was always protective to me like and I appreciated it because she taught me that I still had worth when I didn't see it.

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: I didn't even recognize it. And when I had my son by her, that's another thing that taught me that there was something worth living for because he was precious he was innocent. He was something that I wish I could be innocent. Not having to worry about this or that.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah, something about it. Yeah, so do you have some kind of ongoing relationship with any of the girls that you knew before this happened?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: What to who?

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: With any of the girls, like the mother of your child? Do you have an ongoing relationship with her?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: Yes. She's my best friend. Yeah still to this day.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So who comes and visits you other than your family. You said your sisters and your mom come visit you. Does she come to visit? The mother of your child.

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: No, she has never been to Angola but she came to when I was still in the parish. I stayed in the parish for 4 years from 95 to 99 yeah because she stays in St. Louis so it's a long way.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Why did you stay in the parish for four years? Took that much time for your trial?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: I don't know. Yeah. There's something they was arguing in my case about. The statute of limitations of incarceration about them taking so long. It's just a lot of stuff they had on my case about my charges about proving this and that

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Tell me about your child, a boy or a girl?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: A boy, Jam Arial.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Tell me more about, do you have a relationship with him?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: Oh yeah, my main man! We have a really good relationship. I developed something with him since I've been locked up called how you say it, oh man up. Yeah, I got it from King David and Solomon out of the Bible it started as a program with him about asking questions. Something I'm realized about me and my dad we had no true relationship and I didn't want that for him.

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: So, I would write him and ask him 10 questions about him that I don't know and I would ask that he ask me 10 questions about myself I want you to know. I want you to know who your dad was. I want to clear up some things in case somebody told you something that was wrong.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure that's a really smart way to initiate a relationship.

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: Yeah, I care about what he learning.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Is he able to visit you here?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: Oh yeah, oh man, yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: When was the last time you saw him?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: Well, 2000 he came to all of Returning Hearts. 2016-17. I mean 16.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay- so he's in his 20s not huh?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay any other children aside from him?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: No.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay so prior to this charge, did you have any other run-ins with the law? Any other previous arrests?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: Yeah. I had some arrests. Matter of fact, the fight I had at school, I got arrested for. I never been too juvenile but I ended up going to a juvenile facility for that fight but besides this, I never went to juvenile. I never had a charge on my rap sheet.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Let me ask you this, let's say this didn't happen. Let's say you just didn't get out of bed that morning. What do you think would have happened in the next few years of your life?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: Let me go up a level. I actually got out of jail the day before. The simple burglary charge, I got out the day before and I met this lady and she told me that she had a roofing company and she said "Do you want to work for me?" I said, "I will." She said that if I wanted to start the next day, which was Friday or did I wanted to wait till Monday to start fresh.

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: And these were my exact words to her. I said, "I want to start Friday, tomorrow, because I want to spend as less time in the streets as possible." She looked at my mother and she said, "This is the guy who sounds like he has his mind right." But the next day when I got up to actually call her to go to work, she didn't answer. So I went back home and went to sleep and got up again and called again but this time I got a secretary and the secretary told me to just come in Monday, don't worry about Friday. I never made it past Friday.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So, what do you think would have happened? You would be a roof working for a roofing company?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: I don't know I don't know what I would be. I was rapping too so there's no telling what I would have done.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yep.

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: I think it's actually what I wrote on your paper. I answered all of your questions on my paper. I said that one of those, I just consider it to be one of the options that would have come upon my life because of the environment that I would have gotten killed. It was just something that you automatically know.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So I want to switch gears and talk about the last 22 years, coming up on 23. But before I do, is there something about the first 18 years of your life that's really important in terms of shaping your life that we haven't had a chance to talk about?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: Yeah, my father.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay tell me about that.

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: I just want to say this one thing about him. He died in 2010 but one of the things that has helped me to today even to today, even though we didn't have a good relationship is that he always showed excitement when he saw me. It's like he knew something about me that I didn't know. He was always expecting of me although he was never around but when I would find him, I would always have to find him. I would look all over the city until I found him 200 times.

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: Come to find, he had a whole other family. But I got really cool with the brothers on that side. That's what I can say about him. He always left me happy, even when he wasn't around because he would have this thing with him where he expected something from me- it was something good. It was and he would do it without worries. He would always make these gestures toward me and around me and to people about me but, as far as his presence being there.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So, obviously we are interested in transition and changes that happen in a person right? And so you're as we all are, quite different after 22 years. Can you, just for a second though, just describe the Jerry Brown who was brought in through the gates of Angola? What kind of fellow is he?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: Well, I was 22 at the time. So, I was still kind of energetic, as a softer term to wild. I was cautious. I was studious because I still read a lot. I love reading. I love knowledge.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Did that start in the Parish?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: No, it was on the street too, but I told you that one thing the detective knew about me was that I had good grades. I always was a person that liked to be informed, I always liked to be positive to, I had been around so much negativity.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So, how are you different from that wild person?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: Well, once again, I'm able to see forward. I have foresight now. I'm able to see that one action can cause a ripple effect that can change your destiny forever if you don't look at it strong enough, if you don't think before you decide and you don't decide before you act.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right, its impulse control. Everything to do with brain development. How were your first few months here at Angola?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: Crazy. Because I went to the cell blocks and it was extremely cold yet they still wanted us to go to work call and I didn't understand it. And because of that, I didn't understand how this place was set up because I was like "Why would they want humans outside in that?

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: It's like 22 degrees outside but they wanted us to go out and do work and then when I see the tools, I said "what is that? That's a tool?" You were supposed to cut the grass with it the sling blade, yeah, but it's this big hunk of wood with this big crooked piece of metal on it, so I didn't understand it. Where I'm from, I didn't see anything that looked like that.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So you said "I'm not going to work?"

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: Oh, I went. I went. But a lot of guys had to coach me into what is this but immediately, I was like, "This is inhumane. This is not even, this is unheard of." Yeah. Just didn't make sense to my brain.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, so you refused to work.

transcript.speaker: Jerry
transcript.content: I worked, I stayed I just had to teach me how to do it and explain to the free man that he just came here.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, I get it. You're in the cell blocks, the working cell blocks. And did you find yourself getting into fights here?
